45M with a one month history of jaundice and progressive liver
   failure.  Pt states that he first starting noticing that he had low
   energy last summer.  He is the owner of an auto repair and sales
   business and noted that he was having to sleep all day on his days off
   starig last summer which was unusual for him.  The first week of
   [**Month (only) **], he went to the dentist and was referred to his PCP because
   they notes jaundice.  His PCP did basic liver function test and
   referred him to a hepatologist who subsequently referred him for liver
   biopsy that was performed on [**2187-4-9**].  The patient was not scheduled to
   follow-up with his hepatologist until [**4-30**], however, his father
   suggested that he see another hepatologist sooner.  The patient then
   was seen at Brown.  He has been followed daily since last Friday and
   was transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] today in the setting of worsening renal
   failure on top of liver failure.
   The patient has a history of heavy drinking.  He last drank in [**Month (only) **]
   when his liver failure was diagnosed.  At that point, he drank [**3-6**]
   glasses of wine perday.  He admits that he used to drink to excess and
   that he would consistently drink close to a 6pack of beer a day.  He
   also has a remote history of cocaine and marijuana use.  He smoked 1ppd
   until this diagnosis.  He denies any foreign travel.  He has no sick
   contacts.  [**Name (NI) **] did eat raw oysters the Sunday before he saw his dentist,
   though no one else who dined with him got sick.  Pt also used to abuse
   percocet and vicodin in combination with alcohol.  He states that he
   stopped doing this when he learned that this could be bad for the liver
   several years ago..
   .
   In the ED, vitals 96.9 134/97 83 14 100% RA.  The patient's labs were
   significant for transaminases in the thousands, Tbili of 50 and a Cr of
   3.0.  Ammonia level 101.  RUQ ultrasound performed.
   Liver function abnormalities
   Assessment:
   Alert pleasant man, oriented x3 with some short term memory, Jaundiced.
   LFTs, tot bili remain elevated, BUN/Cr elevated. Difficulty voiding.
   Hemodynamically stable.
   Action:
   CXR and cardiac echo done today. Numerous labs sent. Social work in
   today to chat with pt.
   Response:
   Remains hemodynamically stable. Tolerating regular diet well. A&Ox3,
   MAE.
   Plan:
   Transplant team to discuss potential need for transplant. Will most
   likely need Abd CT though per transplant will require contrast. In
   light of elevated BUN/Cr, d/w team premed prior to CT.  Provide comfort
   and emotional support.
   Renal failure, acute (Acute renal failure, ARF)
   Assessment:
   BUN/Cr 60/4.0, foley placed on day shift with 600cc urine out, and
   80-100cc/hr UO since foley placement.
   Action:
   24hr urine collection started at 1400
 testing for copper. abdominal
   U/S on days looking for hydronephrosis, bladder scan showing 1L fluid
   in bladder, pt reporting difficulty with flow- foley placed on days and
   24 hr urine initiated.
   Response:
   Remains hemodynamically stable, good UO.
   Plan:
   Cont. to monitor UO, collect 24hr urine until 1400 tomorrow.  Monitor
   BUN/Cr. ? hepatorenal failure
